docs.title: Reordering Adjustments
docs.text:
Back to Editing

The adjustments are listed in a common workflow order. For example, many people crop early in the process to make sure that they are only concerning themselves with the part of the image they're interested in. However, other people like to crop at the end, or perhaps they apply white balance correction first. Nitro lets you reorder the adjustments in the UI. To do that, go to Settings and pick Configure.

You can drag adjustments up and down. You can also change the auto-collapse adjustment setting. If it's on, then adjustment sections will open and close automatically as you use them to save space. Note that reordering adjustments only changes the appearance in the UI; it does not change the order that the adjustments are processed to make an image.

docs.title: Slider Basics
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Editing sliders in Nitro have a number of additional features to make it easier to set values. - Reset: Double-click the slider to reset the value (you can also double-click the title of the slider) - Fine-tuning Mode: Drag the slider vertically about 1 inch (2.5 cm) until the slider ball turns green. Then drag horizontally as then the values will update more slowly. - Nudge (Mac only): you can click the arrows next to the slider value to nudge the values up or down. Hold the option key while clicking to move them a smaller amount. - Manual Entry: - Mac: click on the numeric field to type in a new value - iPad and iPhone: tap on the numeric field to get an onscreen mini-keyboard to enter numbers (see below image).

docs.title: Crop
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Let's start with Crop. For most adjustments, you do not need to click the checkbox before working. The checkbox will automatically enable as soon as you start dragging sliders or otherwise working with the adjustment. A reset button will appear as well. You can click the checkbox to turn the adjustment off, or you can clear the adjustment by clicking the reset button.

Crop initially shows a simple view with tools and a straighten slider.

From left to right the tools are: - Crop tool - Straighten tool - Rotate left - Rotate right - Flip vertical - Flip horizontal

The crop tool is mostly self-explanatory; however, an important control appears when you turn it on. In the image below, you can see a number sign button. This controls a rule of thirds guide. Next to it is a megapixel reading that tells you the size of the image after the crop has been applied.

The tool also has a popup menu to set the aspect ratio (or have freeform crop), text fields to set a custom aspect ratio, and text fields to enter a precise crop size and position. Press the "checkmark" button to exit the crop tool. There are two preferences to control how the crop tool works. The first one defaults the crop tool to the original aspect ratio each time. If you turn that off, then the app will use the last aspect ratio (including freeform) for the next image. The second preference will auto-rotate the crop box to match the image's aspect ratio.

You can straighten in a few different ways. First, you can drag the straighten slider, which will display a grid as you do that. Second, you can use the straighten tool. When you engage this tool, you can simply drag on a line in the image that should be level, but isn’t (either a vertical or horizontal line - it doesn’t matter). You may find it is easier to drag just above or to the side of the line in question. That will compute the angle and straighten the image.

docs.title: White Balance
docs.text:
Back to Editing

The white balance adjustment shows the color temperature and tint of the image, and you can adjust them if the image has a tint you want to neutralize (or add). Color temperature is expressed in degrees Kelvin, where lower temperatures result in a bluer image and higher temperatures result in a redder image.

There are also presets for common scenes, such as daylight or fluorescent lighting. One way to adjust white balance is to use the auto white balance control. It looks for an area that it thinks should be a gray value and then changes the temperature and tint so that it matches. Alternatively, you can use an eyedropper. When you use the eyedropper, do something similar to what the auto white balance is doing: look for an area that should be gray. You don't want to choose a white pixel or a very bright one; you don't want something too close to black. Look for a uniform midtone - a patch of color that should be gray, but isn’t -- that gives the white balance algorithm the most latitude. You can also drag the eyedropper to get a white balance change in real-time.

docs.title: Tone
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Next is the Tone adjustment. The tone adjustment is important for controlling brightness in the image. Tone has a large number of sliders.

The first slider is Boost. By default, RAW images can look very flat and lack contrast or “punch.” Boost provides that contrast and punch. Boost is also very important for recovering highlights, and it’s not present in apps from other companies. It controls a key part of Apple's RAW decoder and without control over Boost, highlight recovery is substandard. Boost controls the “look” of the image. The “look” is the mix of contrast, saturation and other sweetening that is applied to a RAW image by default to make it look more appealing. However, in its attempt to make the image look nice, the Boost slider also interferes with highlight recovery, fighting with your attempts to bring down blown-out highlights. You can move the slider yourself, but in Nitro, there's a better way to deal with this problem: use the Recover Highlights Quick Fix (described in detail below). That'll move the Boost slider and other important sliders for you. Note: Boost does not appear for ProRAW images, or non-RAWs like JPEGs and HEIF images, as those file formats do not have the image data necessary to recover highlights. Also, if you want the most control over your RAW images, decrease Boost to 0.5 or shut it off entirely by setting it to 0.0. But if you do that, you will need to do more editing of the image on your own in Nitro.

Exposure is a simple slider for adjusting the entire image's brightness. Setting the value to 1.0 makes every pixel twice as bright. At 2.0, every pixel is four times as bright. Moving the slider to -1.0 makes every pixel half as bright. Highlights just work on the brighter pixels, and shadows are for the darker areas. Midtones are right in the center.

Blacks, Whites, and Boost Shadows are only available for raw images because they control special settings in Apple's decoder. Boost Shadows adjusts the bottom or “black” end of the RAW boost curve, allowing you to manipulate the darker parts of the image. The Blacks slider, in particular, is key for dealing with extremely underexposed areas. It sets the "black point" of the image, which is the value below which all pixels are black (that is, 0.0). Pixels that are black are not affected by Exposure, so if you have a very dark image, you may want to move the Blacks slider in order to "lift" some of the pixels above 0.0, where exposure and other sliders can affect them. The Whites slider works primarily with the brighter parts of the image by modifying the baseline exposure of an image.

Recovery: this slider works like a “selective exposure”. Only the brightest pixels are affected, but unlike highlights, it adjusts the brightness just like exposure. Sometimes you will get better results with Recovery and other times Highlights will work better (or a combination).

docs.title: Clipping Indicators
docs.text:
Back to Editing

As mentioned above, the histogram includes clipping indicator circles at the top. These circles at the top of the histogram clipping indicators are used to identify very bright and very dark parts of the image.

If an image has extremely bright pixels, the circles will light up. If you click on the circles, you get an overlay that shows which pixels are too bright or too dark. Another term for this is clipping because the pixel value is too large to be represented on screen and therefore is clipped to the maximum value of white or black. In other words, the pixel is brighter than the brightest value that can be shown on screen. The first circle is the one you will use most often. It'll show you any pixels that are clipped because they're too bright or are black. In this case, a pixel is considered clipped if any of the components (red, green, or blue) are above 1.0, which is the highest value that is normally seen on a screen. Another word for a clipped pixel is a hot pixel, and a black pixel is sometimes called a cold pixel. If you click on the first circle, you see red for pixels that are too bright and blue for pixels that are black. This is also called a hot and cold pixel overlay. An example appears below.

The other circles are channel-specific clipping indicators, so you can see clipping in just the red, green, or blue channels. There are two histogram-specific preferences. One lets you control how clipping is calculated (all channels or any channel). You can also choose whether histograms are computed in the sRGB or the Display P3 color space. See the Settings interface.

docs.title: Enhance
docs.text:
Back to Editing

The Enhance adjustment contains basic tools like contrast, saturation, and vibrancy.

Vibrancy is like saturation, but it doesn't affect skin tones or orange hues. Deepen and Lighten are smarter versions of Highlights and Shadows. This pair of sliders is similar to Highlights and Shadows but produce better results in general. Deepen operates on the brighter parts of the image, while Lighten operates on the darker parts of the image. The sliders are better than Highlights and Shadows because they do not affect overall image contrast.

docs.title: Detail
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Detail has two basic types of sliders: one for sharpening and one for noise reduction.

Clarity and Sharpen are two types of sharpening sliders. It's best to look at the detail sliders when zoomed in. You can move Sharpen to the left to blur an image. Clarity provides a sharpening effect using a technique called Local Contrast. It is similar, but not identical to the Definition slider found in Photos for Mac and Aperture. In addition, Clarity can go "negative" to soften images.

The noise reduction sliders only appear for RAW images. They can be used to increase or decrease the amount of default noise reduction on an image. The Luminance Noise slider affects black and white noise, while the Color Noise controls noise that looks like colored speckles. Sometimes applying strong noise reduction can cause the image to look flat or “plasticky.” If that happens, consider increasing the value of the Detail slider. It restores some “grain” to the image to make it look more natural.

docs.title: Curves
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Curves is a very powerful adjustment that allows precise manipulation of pixel data. Curves can be thought of as a custom adjustment where you precisely describe the effect on each channel of each pixel. Each curve represents a mathematical equation. The X coordinate is the input value, and the Y coordinate is the output value. In other words, y = f(x). By default, the input and output is the same, resulting in no change to pixels. This is expressed as a 45 degree line, because at every point on such a line, y = x, and therefore no change occurs. Black (0.0) is on the left, and white (1.0) is on the right. The histogram shows the image before the Curves adjustment. As a result, the histogram does not move as you manipulate the curves.

The Curves adjustment consists of four separate curves, one for “Red,” “Green,” and “Blue” and a “Combined” curve. The red, green, and blue curves only affect one channel of each pixel, while the combined curve affects all three channels.

You can tap on a curve to add a point, which you can then drag to the position of your choosing. The image updates in real-time to account for the change in the curve. There are limitations on how close points can be to each other, so sometimes the Nitro will prevent you from adding or moving curve points.

People often use Curves to adjust contrast. To do that, make an S-shaped curve in the Combined channel as shown in the above image. The more it looks like an “S,” the greater the contrast.

At the top of the Curves adjustment are two automatic buttons: Auto Black and White and Auto RGB. Auto Black and White is a good way to make sure your image has good contrast and it inserts multiple points on the gray curve to accomplish that. Auto RGB sets just the black and white points on the red, green, and blue curves, which improves contrast and also corrects color casts in the image. Here is an example image using the Auto RGB control to eliminate the color cast in the image:

Below the Auto controls are color samplers and a menu with more options. The samplers let you place points on the curve by clicking on portions of the image. The first control sets the black point for the image; the second sets the 50% gray point, and the third control sets the white point. Each of these can cause the image to change appearance. The last sampler is the “target” sampler. It places a point on all of the curves at the color value of the pixel you tap on. Except in extreme cases, the target sampler does not affect the image.

Like the White Balance sampler, the curves samplers update continuously if you drag on the image while using them. In the following example, a color cast is removed using the black and white samplers. The sampled points are circled.

Once any point is placed on the curve, you can move it around to adjust the colors similar to the one you sampled.

Right below the curve is the black and white point control (see below). This is the simplest way to set the darkest and lightest colors for a given curve.

You can also add a point manually by clicking on the curve and dragging the point. On the Mac, right-click to get a menu to remove points and make other changes to the curve. On iOS, press and hold on a point to display the menu.

In the "..." menu are some modes. One mode is Gamma vs. Linear. By default, Curves is in gamma mode. When in Gamma mode, Curves gamma-corrects the data before applying the curve data and then reverses the correction before sending the image data to the next adjustment. Gamma is generally a good default, but if you want maximum control over the bright areas of the image, Linear can be a better bet.

The other mode is Equal RGB vs. Luminance. This mode controls the way Curves processes the Combined channel. If it’s set to Equal RGB, then red, green, and blue are affected equally. However, if it is set to Luminance, then the combined curve affects the red, green and blue curves according to the luminance equation, which weights green more heavily, and blue the least. This approach avoids enhancing color casts and is much easier than converting the image to the “Lab” color space in Photoshop and manipulating it that way.

Here is an example using an image with an S-shaped contrast curve. On the left is the image in Equal RGB mode and on the right, in Luminance mode:

A unique feature of Nitro's Curves adjustment is an Extended Range Curve. This is enabled for RAW images only. You can engage it by clicking on the "2" button at the bottom of the interface, as shown below.

When you view the extended range curve, you are seeing a histogram that ranges from 0.0 to 2.0, rather than the standard 0.0 to 1.0. This allows you to manipulate the extremely bright parts of an image precisely, which is impossible with a regular "0 to 1" curve.

docs.title: Levels
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Levels lets you quickly work with the color range of an image. Most people find Levels to be easier to understand than Curves, but it is less powerful than Curves.

Start by either checking the box to enable the Levels controls, or by clicking one of the Auto buttons. Levels defaults to working with the gray channel. Gray and RGB refer to the same channel but show the information differently. RGB shows each channel overlaid, while Gray just shows luminance. The Equal RGB button controls the way Levels processes the Gray channel. If it’s set to Equal RGB, then red, green, and blue are affected equally. However, if it is set to Luminance, then the gray curve affects the red, green and blue curves according to the luminance equation, which weights green more heavily, and blue the least. This approach avoids enhancing color casts and is much easier than converting the image to the “Lab” color space in Photoshop and manipulating it that way.

Like Curves, Levels also includes an Auto Black and Auto RGB feature. Auto Black sets the black and white points on the Gray / RGB channel and will also move the midpoint to add contrast. You can choose the amount of black and white data to be clipped in Preferences. Auto RGB sets the black and white points for the Red, Green, and Blue channels but does not add a contrast point. Auto RGB can correct color casts, when Auto Black is better for general look and contrast issues. In addition, Levels has eye droppers to manually set the black and white points, and you can enter values for the black, mid, and white points. The histogram shows the image before the Levels adjustment. As a result, the histogram does not move as you move the controls in Levels.

docs.title: Perspective
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Perspective corrects images that are shot off-angle, typically off to the side or up from ground level. The filter works by rotating the image three-dimensionally so that the image data looks like it was shot at the proper angle. By default, the perspective adjustment will attempt to fill the image frame, but that may not be desirable in some situations because it can cut off important parts of the image. In that event, use the Zoom Factor slider to expose the full image without cropping. Once you have done that, you can manually crop the image as you like. When you drag the Vertical or Horizontal sliders, a grid appears to make it easier to line up the image to make it straight. Be careful not to over rotate the image — if you do, the image may become warped.

Instead of the sliders, you can select four corners in the image and Nitro will warp the image so that those become the four outermost points on the image. Perspective automatically crops the image. You can decrease that crop by moving the zoom slider, but if you move it too far, you'll get some black areas. You can use the crop tool to remove them.

docs.title: RAW Tuning
docs.text:
Back to Editing

The RAW Tuning adjustment is at the heart of Nitro, providing unique control over Apple’s RAW Engine. All of the sliders are GPU accelerated and real-time, so adjustments appear as soon as you move a slider. There are a few older cameras that don’t have access to all of the below controls, but most do. Note: The RAW Processing adjustment only appears if you are adjusting a RAW image.

Moiré: This slider reduces the effect of moiré. Moiré is an artifact of digital sensors which can cause colored stripes to appear in finely detailed areas. Cameras with an anti-aliasing filter tend to have less moiré, but they also sometimes capture less detail as a result.

RAW Sharpen and RAW Contrast: RAW Sharpen is a subtle form of capture sharpening which works at the Bayer mosaic level. RAW Contrast is a type of local contrast (which can look like sharpening). RAW Contrast generally has a much stronger effect than RAW Sharpen. Both are image-dependent — the characteristics of the image greatly affect how these sliders operate and affect the default values of those sliders. Sony cameras, in particular, are mostly unaffected by the RAW Sharpen slider.

Gamut Mapping: In its final processing step, Apple’s RAW engine ensures colors do not exceed the range of the working color space (Adobe RGB or P3). This is called Gamut Mapping. Colors that are near or outside the limit of that color space are changed to fit within the gamut. Without gamut mapping, colors that exceed the limit of the gamut will be clipped. Gamut Mapping usually provides good results but having control over gamut mapping is helpful in some situations. For example, sometimes you may want the colors to be clipped rather than mapped because you prefer the appearance. Or, you may want to use other filters in Nitro to bring the colors back into gamut.

docs.title: Depth
docs.text:
Back to Editing

The Depth Effect adjustment is available for images shot with the iOS camera in portrait mode. The adjustment allows you to adjust the background and foreground of the image independently. It also provides control over the definition of foreground and background by manipulating the depth mask captured by the camera.

Deepen darkens the brighter pixels but adds richness to the image. Lighten brightens the shadow areas while maintaining contrast. Highlights darkens the brightest pixels in the foreground. Stretch Mask controls what the other sliders consider foreground and background. Sliding it to the left makes more of the image “foreground” and sliding to the right makes more of the image “background”. So, if you move the slider all the way to the left, the entire image is considered “foreground” and the background sliders have no effect. If you move the slider all the way to the right, then very little of the image will be affected by the foreground sliders, while most will be affected by the background sliders. As you change the mask, the image will change to an overlay showing the mask. Lighter shades of gray denote foreground and darker shades denote background.

docs.title: Black and White
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Black and White is a monochrome “mixer” which allows you to make black and white images by controlling the percentages of red, green, and blue that contribute to the grayscale image. Different percentages of these color channels will accentuate different parts of the image and are better for some scenes than others. The Black & White adjustment comes with some presets that simulate the effect of a color filter placed over a camera lens.

If you check the box next to “Black & White,” the adjustment will produce a black and white image using a “luminance” weighting of red, green, and blue. This is generally more pleasing than an equal weighting of the channels, though equal channels is also a preset. A Red filter is good for landscapes and deepens a blue sky. An Orange filter is good for street photography and images with tiles and bricks. A Yellow filter darkens the sky and is generally a good “middle ground” choice. Green is also an interesting choice for landscapes and nature photography. The Blue filter can create a moody shot.

docs.title: HSL (Hue, Saturation, and Luminance)
docs.text:
Back to Editing

The HSL Color adjustment lets you work with individual hues without affecting other hues in your image. To use this adjustment, pick the hue you are interested in, from the nine pre-set hues. Then, adjust the hue, saturation, or luminance of that hue. Similar hues will also be affected, but to a lesser extent. The range slider determines the range of hues affected. If you decrease the range, fewer hues will be changed.

If you increase the range, more hues will be affected. There is an additional choice at the end of the list of preset hues. This is called the “target hue.” The target hue is a custom hue that you choose by clicking and dragging on the image. It works by finding the two preset hues nearest to the one you have chosen and adjusting those proportionally. As with the preset hues, you can choose whether to adjust the hue, saturation or luminance of the target hue. You can choose as many target hues as you like.

docs.title: Split Toning
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Split Toning is an advanced way to adjust images by tinting the highlights or the shadows independently.

There are three tint wheels; the third is an overall tint for the image. In addition, you can adjust the luminance of the highlights, shadows or overall image. The Balance slider controls the dividing line between highlights and shadows. Move it to the right and the range of pixels values considered highlights increases; move it left and the highlight range is reduced. The Balance slider does not affect the Overall tint wheel.

docs.title: Chromatic Aberration
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Chromatic Aberration corrects color shifts that occur when light hits the sensor at an angle, causing the constituent colors to split apart (as in a prism). The signature of an image with chromatic aberration is a colored line (red, yellow, etc.) that appears next to a sharp edge. When that happens, you can use this adjustment to realign the colors and correct the image.

The two sliders control different types of aberration. You will usually see aberration near edges / high contrast areas. If you have red or cyan aberration, use that slider. Otherwise, use the second slider to control blue / yellow aberration. Here is an example of chromatic aberration:

This adjustment can also be used to reduce color fringing. Purple or green fringing can also appear in high contrast areas, such as between tree branches in the winter.

You can reduce this effect with the purple (or green) intensity slider. The range of purple or green hue that is affected can be controlled with the range sliders. Take care with the range slider as it can affect other parts of the image with nearby hues.

docs.title: Lens Correction
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Nitro includes two types of lens correction to handle artifacts in lenses such as distortion and shading (also called vignetting). There are two types of lens correction in the app: automatic and manual. The automatic lens correction is provided by Apple's RAW decoder, but is only available for some camera and lens combinations. Apple's system works by reading lens metadata written into the image file (called a Lens Profile). In general, they can correct newer cameras and lenses, rather than older ones. When Apple's decoder can correct a lens, Nitro defaults to using that correction. You can add further devignetting to Apple's correction, though this is not usually necessary. When the decoder cannot correct a lens automatically, the full suite of manual tools is enabled. If you want to turn off Apple's correction, then press the "Disable Lens Profile" button, which will enable the distortion sliders. They will also be enabled when an image does not have a lens profile. In that case, Nitro will display "No Lens Profile Available".

The manual correction is better described as "semi-automatic." The best way to correct a lens is to take a number of pictures of a grid with that camera and lens combination at a range of aperture values and focal lengths. Then it is straightforward to correct the distortion and shading. The lens correction is semi-automatic because Nitro will learn how to correct the lens automatically using your manual corrections. In short order, Nitro can correct the lens on its own. The AUTO button at the top can be used to correct the lens automatically once there is sufficient information in Nitro's lens correction database. There are also preferences in the app that controls whether this semi-automatic correction engages without your having to click the Auto Button. That is described in more detail in the Settings section.

To learn more about how to correct a lens with Nitro and to build up its correction database, please watch this video (it covers the RAW Power app, but the technique is identical):

Lens Correction Video

Lens Correction support for Compressed Fujifilm and Nikon HE/HE* images is a relatively recent addition to Nitro. If you edited images in previous releases using manual lens correction, and they now can get Apple's lens correction, you will see a Update Lens Correction button in the interface. Follow the steps listed. You can also select multiple images and use the "Update Lens Correction" batch command.

docs.title: Channel Mixer
docs.text:
Back to Editing

A channel mixer is a very powerful tool for tinting images or completely changing the look of your image. You can even swap channels (exchanging blue for red, for example).

Click on the three-color control to choose the color channel to manipulate. Then determine the amount of red, green, and blue data to copy into that channel. The Constant slider simply adds red, green, or blue to the image for a quick tinting effect.

docs.title: Vignette
docs.text:
Back to Editing

Vignette darkens (or lightens) the edges of an image. When darkening an image, it draws the eye to the lighter part of the image (typically the center, or the subject of the image). Vignettes in most photo applications are center-based, making them poor choices if the subject is not in the center of image (as is often the case).

The Vignette in Nitro allows you to specify the center point. To do this click the targeting control next to the reset button and then click and drag on the image. You might want to increase the intensity of the effect before changing the center point to make it easier to see what will happen. Vignette applies its effect after crop, so if you want to lighten the edges of an image before crop is applied to counteract lens shading, then use the Devignette tool in the Lens adjustment.

docs.title: Masking
docs.text:
Back to top

Masking is a very powerful feature of Nitro. It allows you to work selectively on regions of an image, applying adjustments just to the area you are interested in. For example, you might want to sharpen the eyes of a person in a portrait without sharpening their skin. Or apply a black and white treatment to the background of an image while leaving the foreground in color. Or a selective adjustment like HSL might allow you to make the sky more blue, but you don't want it to affect a person's blue shirt elsewhere in the image. Linear gradients are ideal for working with skies while radial gradients help with making natural lighting effects.

Note: Nitro uses the term "mask" in the opposite manner of a traditional darkroom. In a darkroom, the mask is the area that is not affected, while in Nitro, the mask is the area that is affected.

You access the masking interface by picking the last of the four main editing modules:

docs.title: Mask Types
docs.text:
Start by adding a mask. There are several types:

  1. Brush Mask: use painting tools to define the area of the image you want to work on.
  2. Linear Gradient: a smooth rectangular area which can be rotated, inverted, or flipped.
  3. Radial Gradient: a circular mask with a gradient inside of it. You can rotate, resize, or stretch it into an ellipse.
  4. AI Subject Mask: makes a mask of the foreground subject using a machine learning model.
  5. AI Background Mask: makes a mask of the background using a machine learning model.

Once you have created a mask, you can modify it, and you can also apply adjustments to it. Each mask can have a large number of adjustments applied to it. Most Nitro adjustments can be applied to a mask. For example, you can create two masks and apply different White Balance corrections to adjust for a mixed lighting situation.

Depending on the type of mask you create, Nitro will provide you with mask editing tools. For a brush mask or an AI mask, Nitro will enable the painting tools. For a linear or radial gradient, Nitro will show the gradient on-screen tools to move or rotate the gradient.

Please note that you can brush any mask in Nitro, including AI masks and gradients. This is an extremely powerful way to tune an AI mask or gradient to be exactly what you want with a minimum of effort.

docs.title: Brushing
docs.text:
As mentioned above, you can brush any mask in Nitro. The brushing tools appear below the mask menu:

The first tool, paint, lets you add to a mask. The erase tool removes from a mask. The third tool provides ways to control the mask by color, brightness, or intensity.

docs.title: Painting and Erasing
docs.text:
To paint, start by selecting the paint brush. These are the brush parameters:

  • Size - how big the outer edge of the brush is (all brushes are circular)
  • Strength - how much paint is applied (this can be also be considered opacity)
  • Softness - brushes have a solid interior which gradually fades toward the outer edge. The softness controls how much of the brush is solid. Nitro shows the brush as two concentric circles so you can see how softness works.

To change any of these parameters, tap or click on the numeric value (in the image, tap on the 25, 100, or 50). That will enable the slider below the numbers. The brush cursor will update in real time to show you how the brush will change.

The last control is Edges. This enables an “edge aware” or “contour following” brush mode. When you turn on Edges, Nitro’s brush will paint only on one side of an edge, allowing you to follow contours. It can take a little practice but it’s extremely powerful. However, you will want to use the brush in both Edge On and Edge Off modes for best results.

You can see the effectiveness of the edge aware brush in the below image, where the red area is the brushed area.

Below the brush size slider are a few quick actions: * Fill will completely fill the mask. The next step is usually to use the eraser to remove portions of the mask. This is useful if you want to apply an effect to most of the image. * Clear makes the mask empty so you can start over again. * Invert reverses the mask. This can be useful if you want to work on the opposite area that you painted (for example, the area is very large, so you paint on the small area you don’t want to affect, and then invert).

When you are done painting, tap the blue checkmark to exit the painting mode.

docs.title: Mask Options
docs.text:
Also in the painting interface are mask options, as shown below.

  • Luminance lets you set a range of luminance values. Outside of that range the mask has no effect. This is helpful when targeting only bright or dark areas.
  • Color Range lets you establish a range of colors to affect.
  • Intensity lets you dial up or down the amount of the masked effect (like the opacity of a layer).

Each mask can have its own mask options.

docs.title: Mask Overlays
docs.text:
Next to the paint tools is a half circle which represents the Mask Overlay options which control a visual overlay of the mask itself.

  • No Overlay: the mask is not visible, other than through the adjustments applied.
  • On Black Overlay: the mask is drawn, but the image is not drawn.
  • Rubylith Overlay: a red overlay appears.
  • Translucent Rubylith: same as the rubylith, but it has some transparency to help you see the image behind it.

docs.title: Moving a Gradient Mask
docs.text:
Linear and Radial Gradients can be repositioned. Because you can also brush on a gradient mask, to move a gradient select the last of the four tools which looks like a four directional arrow. On screen controls appear to let you move or resize the gradient.

  • Invert: this switch lets you reverse the gradient’s effective area.
  • Constrain: this switch limits a radial gradient to a circle and linear gradient to 45 degree angles.
  • Ramp: this slider lets you control how the gradient falls off from maximum to minimum.

docs.title: Switching Masks and the Mask Menu
docs.text:
Switch between masks by first tapping the blue checkmark. Then use the Mask popup menu to choose a different mask (or use the Add popup menu to create a new mask)

Next to the Add and Mask popup menus is the Mask Options button. This brings up a menu with more commands.

  • Duplicate: creates a duplicate of the current mask. You can rename the mask.
  • Duplicate and Invert: creates a duplicate mask but inverts the contents.
  • Rename Mask: allows you to rename a mask to be more descriptive
  • Delete Mask: removes the mask from the image
  • Reset Edits for Mask: removes the edits from the mask
  • Include Edits when Duplicating: If checked, then the Duplicate and Duplicate and Invert commands will also copy the edits to the duplicate mask.

Note: the Duplicate commands are in Nitro version 2025.1 and are not available in earlier versions.

docs.title: RAW + JPEG Editing in Photos
docs.text:
When browsing the Photo library, RAW + JPEG image pairs are represented by a single thumbnail. The thumbnail shown is the one made by Photos, or is the result of editing either the RAW or the JPEG. Photos defaults to editing the JPEG, while Nitro defaults to editing the RAW. There are a few different ways to control which one is edited. While in Edit, if you have an R+J image, you can switch between the two with the R+J button. It is located next to the 4-way control as shown here:

Click that button to switch between the two images. If you switch to the JPEG, adjustments that are RAW-only will disappear, and vice-versa. In addition, on the Mac, you can right-click on the Viewer to switch, or use the Image menu. Finally, in Settings, you can choose whether the RAW or the JPEG is the default.

docs.title: Editing on iPhones
docs.text:
Back to top

Nitro has a different user interface on iPhones, due to the tall and narrow shape of the device. Most controls are on the bottom of the screen and more menu choices are in the “...” menu at the upper left. The app opens into the last album or folder you viewed. To access the other folders / albums, tap the Library button in the upper left. Below are some screenshots of the interface:

The library view on iPhones is the same as found on iPads, with the same controls and switcher to go between the Photo Library and the Files.app view. If you are using the Photo Library, you can also use the Album picker at the bottom to jump between some commonly accessed albums. The bottom of the grid view also has two arrow buttons to jump to the top or bottom of the thumbnail view. The Select button remains in the grid view, which you can use to share, delete, or run batch operations. However, many other commands have been moved to the “...” menu in the upper right as shown below.

If you rotate your iPhone to landscape orientation, the interface will adapt to a more-iPad like design, though the app is optimized for use in portrait screen orientation. Tap on a thumbnail to go to the Viewer.

docs.title: One Up (Viewer)
docs.text:
The viewer is similar to the one on iPads, except all the controls have moved to the bottom of the screen.

Here, you can rate, flag, and mark images as favorites. There is also a bottom toolbar with share, info, help, and trash. The info button uses the “flip tiles” method of showing metadata, which will show a map if the image has location information.

You can tap the share button to bring up an export panel. To adjust the export settings, tap the Change button; a summary of the export settings appears at the bottom of the panel. To enter Edit, tap the Edit button in the upper right.

The most obvious difference with Edit is that the controls are on the bottom of the screen.

docs.title: Edit Basics
docs.text:
On iPhones, Edit is laid out vertically. At the top of the screen is an Info button which will display a reduced set of metadata as shown below. Right below the image is a toolbar. The final button contains some configuration options.

Tap the info button again to hide the shot information. The buttons below the image are as follows:

The histogram on iPhones works very differently from the one on iPads and Macs. It floats above the image.

Clipping indicators are present at the top, along with a “...” menu to set the top-most channel.. You can drag the histogram to place it where you like. In the toolbar below the image, you can Nitro’s unique histogram options (only for the iPhone). The four options work as follows:

  • Show: always shows the histogram
  • Don’t Show: always hides the histogram
  • Only While Adjusting: displays the histogram when you are moving a slider or a curve / level control. This lets you adjust with the histogram visible without it interfering with the image.
  • Only While Not Adjusting: displays the histogram when you are not actively moving a slider or curve / level control. This lets you see the entire image while adjusting, while displaying the histogram at other times.

docs.title: Editing
docs.text:
As mentioned before, the editing tools are at the bottom of the screen on iPhones. There are three modes on the left: Quick Fixes, Presets and LUTs and Masks. After those are the slider adjustments.

Tap any icon to view that adjustment or mode. When you change an adjustment, or add a mask, the icon turns blue, as shown above for the Tone adjustment. You can tap on the numbers above sliders to display an onscreen numeric keypad.

Most adjustments look similar on iPhones as on iPads. The biggest differences are the need to scroll to see all the sliders, and a specific mode for Curves. This is the default view for Curves. If you tap the “Large” button, the curve appears on top of the image and you can interact with it there (and the Curve interface area gets shorter to give you more space).

Which to use is personal preference, though one could also use the default view for simple adjustments (like black and white point) and the overlay view for detailed work.

docs.title: Masking
docs.text:
Masking is also different on iPhones. The basic controls are the same, but there are a few additional things to keep in mind.

To enter masking, tap the Masks button at the bottom. You will see a display like the one shown above on the left. Tap the Add menu button to add a mask - the same types of masks are available on iPhones as on Macs and iPads. Also note the blue Exit button above that area. That is the way you exit masking. An exit button is needed because the same adjustment icons are available for masking as for regular editing, so a mode is required so it’s clear whether you are editing the entire image, or the adjustments for a particular mask. Once you create (or choose a previously-created mask), the brushing tools appear, with the same options and controls as iPads and Macs have.

docs.title: External Editing (Mac)
docs.text:
Back to top

External Editing is a Mac-only feature that integrates Nitro with other apps on your Mac. You can select an image in the Nitro grid and then send it to an external editor app. The list of apps is built automatically by Nitro by querying macOS for apps that announce that they can edit images. Then macOS returns a set of apps satisfying that requirement and Nitro then builds the menu. When you select an app, Nitro will also ask which type of file you want to send to the other app. Nitro also allows you to add your own custom editors to the list, and also limit the list to just those custom editors.

The choices for file format are as follows: * Original Image * JPEG * TIFF 8 bit * TIFF 16 bit

You also have choices for color profile: * sRGB * AdobeRGB * Display P3 * ProPhoto RGB * BT 2020

If you request the original file, then the color profile is disabled and has no effect. Otherwise, Nitro will render a new file and send it to the other app. The image will be stored next to the original (again unless you are sending the original, in which case no extra file is made).

This feature is only available when using Finder folders. That is because Photos is responsible for managing images in the library. It is unsafe to manage files outside of Photos’ control. Further, Apple does not provide a way for 3rd parties to import images into the Photo library by reference, so if the feature existed for the Photo Library, it would fail for referenced images (or it would put the externally edited image inside the library folder.

docs.title: Metadata and ExifTool
docs.text:
Back to top

Nitro shows metadata in multiple ways. The primary way is via the Info button in the right side panel. This image shows the various controls available on either side of the main viewer window:

If you pick the Info button, then you will get three sections of metadata. The first is shot information, as shown here:

This information is also visible when in the Edit interface, though you can also collapse it to get more working space vertically.

The second section contains a map with location information, if there is GPS data in the image.

You can drag the map to move it and there are also different view options (Satellite and Road).

The last section contains miscellaneous metadata that varies from camera to camera:

This information is not editable.

On the Mac, you can also access much more extensive metadata with Nitro's Exiftool integration. To access ExifTool, click the EXIF button in the right side panel.

You can filter to show specific Exif keys and you can also click the "heart" icon to establish favorites. If you click the "heart" at the top (next to the search field), then Nitro will only show your favorites.

The last way that metadata is presented is via Info "tiles", also called the "Flip View". To access that mode, pick the icon below the main Info button. That will display metadata inside the viewer itself. This is an example with a single image:

On the Mac, you have access to ExifTool directly, so you can search for metadata.

Because metadata is shown in the viewer itself, Flip View is able to show metadata for multiple images at once. To do that, enter either Compare Mode or N-Up Mode. If you then select multiple images and pick Flip View, you will see metadata side by side as shown below.

If you search in the ExifTool area, Nitro will filter all images by the same string.

On iPhone, this flip view is the primary way that metadata is displayed, due to the smaller screen. In Edit, you can access shot information by tapping the Info button at the top of the screen as shown below.

docs.title: Keywords
docs.text:
Note: Currently, editing keywords is limited to the file system. That's because Apple does not provide an official way to work with keywords in the Photo Library. I have provided a way to view and filter keywords in the Photo Library, but not modify or add them (you can do that in Photos on the Mac). If Apple provides full keyword access in the future, then I’ll add it to Nitro. The interface will work the same way as it does for the file system. Also, this feature is not currently available on the iPhone. There simply isn’t enough space to add it - that may change in the future.

You can view keywords in the Info panel as shown below (see the red rounded rectangle).

You can also filter for keywords in the standard filtering interface. Nitro will show all the keywords in the current folder / album. You can filter for keywords in the container, or for keywords NOT in the container, as well as AND / OR searches.

Nitro is able to read keywords in XMP files added by other apps, so you can use keywords even if you do not use Nitro's keyword interface.

docs.title: Keyword Editor
docs.text:
There are multiple ways to add and remove keywords. The first way is using the new Keyword Editor, which you access by tapping on the button that looks like a tag in the right side panel (indicated in yellow in the above image). The Keyword Editor looks like this:

Keywords already on the image are at the top. Press the X button to remove them. You can undo and redo changes you make in this view. Changes to keywords are saved when you go to another image, or return to the grid.

You can type into the Add Keyword which will autocomplete based on the current keyword list.

Nitro keyword lists are hierarchical, so if you add a keyword, it will also add the parent keywords. Nitro doesn’t store the hierarchy in the XMP file - the hierarchy lets you organize keywords and search efficiently. You can also add a bunch of keywords by typing them all together, separated by commas.

NOTE: keywords that begin with a tilde (~) will not be added when a child is picked. This allows the hierarchy to organize using some generic terms (such as "Image Type") that won't be added as keywords.

TIP: You can resize the keyword area at the top by dragging on the grabber that is right below the Add Keyword text field.

docs.title: Keyword Lists
docs.text:
Nitro comes with about 1000 keywords, organized into a hierarchy. In addition, Nitro has localized versions of this keyword list, so there is a keyword list in German, French, Spanish, Japanese, and Chinese. The app will automatically load the correct one for the language you are using; if you are using a language other than English, then Nitro will include both the localized keyword list and the English one.

In addition to auto-complete in the Add Keyword, you can filter for them. Tap on a keyword to add it (and its parents) to the image. The heart icon represents favorites. You can favorite keywords. Then tap the heart next to the search field to filter by them.

There are also keyword options. Press the Keyword Lists to display a menu. The check mark shows the current keyword list (called Default). You can import keyword lists, and also edit a keyword list (including the default one). The last choice displays the folder with the keyword lists the app is using. You can remove files there if you like. But if you do, restart Nitro so it reads them back in.

Keyword Lists have a specific format. Each keyword is on a separate line and hierarchy is handled with tab characters. You can use the Show My Keyword Lists menu item and open at the default keyword list in a text editor if you want to see what they look like. Also, do not include commas, semicolons, or pipe characters ("|"). Also do not end keywords with an asterisk ("*")

docs.title: Editing a Keyword List
docs.text:
The simplest reason to edit a keyword list is to add a set of keywords to the default list, or remove ones you don’t like. Here is the interface. It’s mostly self-explanatory. You can delete keywords, rename them and move them around. Changes to a keyword list do not change images that have been tagged already. Tap/Click in the background of a keyword row to select it. Press the New button to add a new keyword at the same level as the selected keyword. The + Child button adds a child to the selected keyword.

As far as reordering, if you move a keyword into an expanded list, then it will move it there. If you try to move a keyword to a keyword that is closed, then it goes into the parent’s level. You can expand the one you want to move it there. There are also the promote and demote buttons that you can use to move items in the hierarchy.

By the way, if you mess up the default keyword list in the app - don’t worry. Pick “Show My Keyword Lists” in the Keyword List menu, find the Default Keyword List and delete it. Then quit and reopen the app. The app will then copy a fresh file for your use.

There is also a copy/paste command for keywords. On the Mac, you can get to that in the Metadata menu. Pick an image with keywords and select Copy Keywords. Then pick one or more images and select Paste Keywords.

On the Mac you can do it by going to the Metadata menu and choosing Add / Remove Keywords.

You may have noticed the AI button in the keyword editor interface. Nitro also has the ability to generate keywords using AI. You can do that here in 1-up or batch assign them. The interfaces are basically the same, which will be discussed in the next section.

docs.title: Batch Keywords
docs.text:
There are three ways to assign keywords to a bunch of images at once. On the Mac, you can use the Add / Remove Keywords menu in the Metadata menu. You can also right-click on an image and display the contextual menu. On the iPad, you can use the Batch interface or the contextual menu. This is the interface:

The batch interface looks a lot like the Keyword Editor. At the top is a set of keywords and then the Add and keyword list below that. However, because you can have more than one image selected, the Batch interface has to indicate which keywords are on all selected images and which are only on some images. The checkmark indicates the keyword is on all images and the dash indicates it’s only on some images.

If you tap on a keyword with a dash, it will replace the dash with a checkmark. That means that the keyword will be applied to all selected images. If you have a keyword with a checkmark and tap it, then the checkmark will be removed and there will be no indicator. That means it will be deleted from all images that have it. There is also undo and redo right in the panel.

docs.title: Automatic Keywording
docs.text:
Nitro can automatically generate keywords. You access that feature the same way as Batch Keywords: menus on the Mac, and contextual menus or the Batch button on iPads. There is also a blue AI button in the Keyword Editor. This is a brand new AI model that is small enough and efficient enough to run on your device. The interface looks like this:

As the text at the top says, all AI processing is done on your iPad or Mac and none of your images are uploaded to the cloud. Currently, the model only works in English. A future release may add additional languages.

To keep the download of Nitro small, the models are not stored inside the Nitro app. So the first time you use it, Nitro will download the models to your machine. They are stored in the Caches directory, so if you get low on disk space, iOS or MacOS will remove the files automatically and Nitro will then download them again.

After downloading, the app will load the models. The first time you use the feature on a given launch of Nitro, it will take a few seconds to load - it’s getting a bunch of Apple technology running. After that it will be faster. Then it runs the model and determines a set of keywords for each image individually. You can tap on each image to see what it came up with. We all know that AI is not 100% accurate, so there is a control at the bottom that lets you control the number of keywords it displays. You can also delete keywords from the list that you don’t like or aren’t correct for the image. Press Save to store them to XMP files.

TIP: the keywords it is using come from the same default keyword set. So, if you add or remove keywords from there, the app will use that updated list when running the AI model, which means the model will only recommend keywords that are in the list - giving you more control over the output. That said, not every word and term is recognized by the model.

docs.title: Batch Processing
docs.text:
Back to top

You use batch processing to work with multiple files together, rather than at the same time. The most common example of batch processing is probably batch export, where multiple images are exported with a common set of export parameters.

On iPads and iPhones, you trigger batch processing by using the Select button to choose the images, and then tapping the Batch button. A collection of operations appears, which are described below:

  • Export
  • Paste Most Recent Edit
  • Auto Enhance… (version 2025.1 and later)
  • Apply Preset…
  • Rotate left and right
  • Revert to Original
  • Flag / Reject / Remove Flag (version 2025.1 and later)

You can also press the Trash Can icon after using Select to batch-delete files. On the Mac, you can select images and use the trash can or Cmd-Delete.

In addition there are three other advanced operations:

  • Build Thumbnails: this makes a new thumbnail from the image(s). This is useful when the thumbnail in your image is poor quality or has incorrect orientation.
  • Reindex Images: this is useful when the database is out of date for some reason but it’s best to only use that in conjunction with a conversation with support@gentlemencoders.com
  • Reconnect XMP Sidecars: If you pick it, the app will look for all the sidecars and rename them to have a lower-case extension. This is a rarely used feature, but if you find that the app is unexpectedly not processing your sidecars, check the file extension and use this feature to fix them. There is more information in the section on XMP.

On the Mac, these operations are available either through the main menu (usually in the Image menu) or via the contextual menu when you right-click on an image.

docs.title: Restrictions in Edit
docs.text:
Nitro reduces the set of batch operations while you are in Edit. In general, you cannot perform most of these actions using the Batch menu (or the Image menu on Mac) on the image currently being edited. That restriction may be removed in the future, but for now, simply use the analogous button in the Edit interface. For example, rather than use Apply Preset from the menus, go to the Preset interface in Edit. Export and Flagging are exceptions - those work on images in Edit as they do not affect the editing data itself.

Note: If you want to apply a batch operation to both the currently edited image and other images not being edited, then exit Edit and then apply the action. That way, the edits are saved, and the operation can run. The simplest way is to click on the edit button on the right side panel which closes the edit panel and saves the edits.

docs.title:
Export

Back to top

Export is the primary way to get images out of Nitro. The options for export vary depending on the platform you are using and where you are using the Photo Library or not.
Export Operations
docs.text:
On iOS, there are the following export options.

The following table describes when those options are available. Yes means it is always available. No means it is never available. Otherwise, the notation indicates whether it’s available when using the Photo Library or File System (Finder / Files.app).

Action iOS Mac Save a new image to the File System Yes Yes Save a new image to the Photo Library Yes Yes Copy original and rating / adjustment metadata to Photo Library Files.app Finder Copy original and rating / adjustment metadata to File System Photo Library Photo Library Share a new image to another app Yes No Share original and rating / adjustment metadata to another app Yes No Share original (only) to another app Yes No Update image in Photo Library* iOS 16 macOS 13

The last item requires extra discussion. In iOS 16 / macOS 13 and earlier, any time a 3rd party app edited an image in the Photo Library, Photos would display a confirmation dialog. This dialog could not be suppressed. It made it very difficult to edit a series of images because the dialog would appear for each image. This was finally removed in iOS 17 and macOS 14 (Sonoma). To make the dialog less of an obstacle to smooth editing, Nitro has two modes of operation, and the default varies depending on OS version. * On iOS 17 / macOS 14 and later: Nitro will commit edits to the library when saving them. * On iOS 16 / macOS 13: Nitro will save edits locally rather than committing them to the Photo Library. You would then use Export to commit the edits to the library. The app will remind you to do that periodically. There are preferences to control this behavior, which are discussed in more detail in that section of this manual.

docs.title: Export Settings
docs.text:
In addition to the operation, you can choose how the image is generated.

  • Name: lets you set a custom name (see Batch Export for details on setting names for multiple files)
  • Format: Choices include JPEG, TIFF (8 and 16 bit), HEIF (8 and 10 bit), and PNG (8 and 16 bit).
  • Compression: compression quality, including lossless for TIFF and PNG.
  • DPI / PPI: sets a metadata tag for the dots / pixels per inch. This has no effect on the image rendered, but can be helpful for printers and similar devices.
  • Color Profile: choices include sRGB, AdobeRGB, Display P3, ProPhoto RGB and BT.2020. To avoid banding when using a wide-gamut format like AdobeRGB, Display P3, ProPhoto RGB and BT 2020, I recommend selecting either 10 or 16 bits for the format.
  • Output Size: you can export to full size, a set of specific sizes (like 1024 pixels), or custom sizes. Note: Nitro does not upscale images at this time.
    • Fit to Longer Edge will take a single number and size the image so that the longer edge is the desired size (while ensuring the image retains its same aspect ratio)
    • Fit to Shorter Edge will take a single number and size the image so that the shorter edge is the desired size (while ensuring the image retains its same aspect ratio).
    • Fit to Width and Height sizes the image to fit within a rectangle defined by the custom size values.
  • Metadata: choices for including different metadata in the file.
  • Watermark: you can apply a watermark to exported image. That is described more in the Watermarking section below.
  • Border: you can apply a border to exported image. That is described more in the Borders section below.
  • Copyright: you can enter a copyright to store in the IPTC copyright field.
  • On the Mac, there are also After Export Actions, which are described below.

In addition, ratings and keywords are stored into the exported file automatically (unless you choose not to export IPTC metadata).

Note: export on iPhone looks and works a little different. See the section Editing on iPhones for more information.

docs.title: Batch Export
docs.text:
If you want to export or share multiple files at once, use Batch Export. On iOS, start by tapping the Select button and choosing the images. Then tap the Batch button. On macOS, select images as you would normally and then use File > Export…

The basic export interface is similar for batch export, except for file naming:

When exporting multiple files, you can specify custom names as follows. For all examples below, the original file name is “IMG_8625”.

  • Original Name: outputs “IMG_8625” with the desired file extension for the output format.
  • Original Name + Date: uses a YYYY-MM-DD format, as in “IMG_8625-2025-01-24”
  • Original Name + Suffix: you specify a number or a number with a character, as in “-1”, so you might see “IMG_8625-1”
  • Custom Name + Sequence: You specify the name and a starting number. There is an optional padding field as well. So, if you entered a custom name of Vacation and a starting number of 100 and a padding of zero, you would see “Vacation-100.JPG”.
  • Custom Name + Date + Sequence: includes the date, resulting in “Vacation-2025-01-24-100”

docs.title: Export Actions
docs.text:
After Export Actions are a Mac-specific feature that lets you open another app after export completes. This works for a single image export or a batch export. The list of apps displayed are all apps that announce to macOS that they can view a JPEG (some apps can view images, but not edit them, so this list is longer than the list of editors).

In addition to viewer apps, Nitro includes Reveal in Finder and the “Default App” which is whatever app you have chosen to open image files with the file format you are exporting.

docs.title:
Watermarking

Back to top

Watermarking is the process of applying a partially transparent image or block of text to an image. This is usually done to protect the rights to an image or intellectual property. Nitro has a powerful watermarking feature that you set up in the Export interface (on the Mac, there is also a menu item: Nitro > Watermark Setup…

Below is the watermark interface for text:

For any watermark, you can position it in any of six locations by clicking or tapping on the appropriate dot (left side of the dialog).

You can also specify opacity, the size of the watermark, and the inset from the dot. The X inset moves the watermark left or right and the Y inset moves it up and down.

For a text watermark, you type in custom text, with a choice of font and color. Some default colors are also offered. In addition you can use an outlined-treatment for the text which makes look a bit more subtle on the image.

For image watermarks, tap the “Use an Image” control, which displays this interface:

You can choose images from the photo library or the file system (Finder / Files.app). The same controls for opacity, size, and position are offered.

Nitro currently only supports a single watermark, though there are plans to allow multiple watermarks and choose them at export time.

Borders

Back to top

Nitro allows you to add a border to an image during export. The border rests on top of the image, so if the border is too wide, it can cover portions of your image. You set up borders in the Export dialog. Press the Setup button next to the Border popup to get started. You can create multiple borders and choose between them in the Export dialog.

Below is the interface to set up and manage borders:

In the example above, you can see two borders have been created, with different colors and thicknesses. Start by pressing the New button to add a border and configure it using controls. There are also buttons to edit, duplicate, or delete borders. You can use standard swipe gestures to delete a border from the list. For a custom color, press the “Choose” button in the row labeled “Color”.

Press the Save button to save the borders. Then in export, select the border you want to use (or No Border if you do not want a border applied).
Display Modes
docs.text:
Back to top

Nitro has three display modes for the Viewer. A single image (sometimes called One-Up), multiple images (N-Up Mode), and a dedicated comparison mode (Compare Mode). Both Compare Mode and N-Up Mode are entered by clicking or tapping an icon on the right side panel.

One-Up is entered initially when exiting the grid, and also by exiting Compare Mode or N-Up (in other words, it’s the default display mode). Neither N-Up nor Compare Mode are available on iPhones due to the limited screen space. One-Up is described earlier in this manual, so this section will focus on the other two modes.

N-Up and Compare Mode are quite similar, but there are a few key differences, which will be noted.

docs.title: N-Up
docs.text:
Back to top

N-Up allows you to see images larger than in the grid, and to edit multiple images as well. When in N-up, the file name is displayed at the bottom of the image. There is one image that receives an outlined border; that is the primary selection and is the one that receives editing, rating and other commands. To change the primary selection, click or tap on one of the other images. To add or remove items from the displayed images:

  • macOS: use the command or shift key while selecting images
  • iOS: tap on a selected image to deselect, and tap on a deselected image to add it.

A key control is visible above the images: Synchronize Pan (and Zoom). When checked, zooming one image will zoom all of them. Panning one image will pan all of them. However, when it is unchecked, only one image will be affected. If you use the keyboard shortcuts or buttons to zoom, then the primary selection is affected. Otherwise, if you are using a trackpad or pinch gestures, then the affected image is the one you are interacting with.

In addition, the Info Flip (or Metadata Tiles) view changes behavior in N-Up and Compare mode. All images will flip to reveal metadata, as shown below.

On macOS, when searching for EXIF metadata, all of the tiles will update simultaneously as shown below:

N-Up is limited to four images on iPads and sixteen images on Macs. You exit N-Up Mode by clicking or tapping on the N-Up Mode icon.

docs.title: Compare
docs.text:
Back to top

Compare Mode is very similar to N-Up, in terms of zoom, panning and metadata. However, there is a key difference in terms of selection and purpose. The purpose of Compare Mode is to make it easier to compare similar images and to then select the best of them. It works by “pinning” one image on the left of the display and then letting you cycle through other images with the arrow key or by tapping / clicking. Only two images are ever displayed in Compare Mode. The left image does not change as you add or remove items from the selection. Further, it is not the “primary selection” - instead the image on the right is the primary selection. There are two buttons on the top of the display area.

The first button swaps the two images, making the right image the “pick.” The second image selects the pick and exits Compare Mode. You can also exit Compare Mode by clicking or tapping on the Compare Mode icon.

docs.title:
Single File Editor

Back to top

Nitro normally operates by showing the contents of folders on your device, or browsing the Photo Library. However, on Macs, there is a third option, called the Single File Editor (SFE). This is a way to edit a single file on your computer using Nitro. There are four ways to access the SFE: * File > Open (or Open Recent) * Drag a file to the app icon * Use the Finder’s Open With command * Use an app that can send files to Nitro

You can have as many SFE windows / tabs as you want, but each one can only edit that one file.

Depending on where the file is located, you may see a privileges alert that looks like this:

There is a bug in macOS where sometimes Nitro cannot store editing information into the XMP file. Nitro will display this alert and then show an Open panel that you can use to resolve the issue. If you want to use the SFE for a large number of directories, you can pick a higher level (parent) folder or give Nitro full disk access in System Settings.

After the file is opened, the interface mostly resembles the regular Nitro edit environment with some key differences. First, the toolbar is different:

The tools are editing-focused, along with Save and Export buttons. The editing environment is the same, except that a) the sidebar is not visible and b) the right side panel removes functions that are not applicable (such as viewing thumbnails or Compare Moe). However, Copy Edits and Paste Edits are still available, which makes it easy to copy edits between SFE windows.

While there is a Save button, explicitly saving is not necessary. Closing the SFE window or tab is sufficient to save your edits.

Enhanced RAW Support

Back to top

Nitro relies on Apple’s RAW camera support to decode RAW images for display and editing. Apple’s decoder has been part of iOS, iPadOS, and macOS for years, and produces very good images. Apple also includes support for hundreds of cameras and formats. However, despite these strengths, Apple has been slow to add support for cameras, and recently support has reached glacial rates. This leaves many photographers unable to view or edit images from newer cameras in Apple’s Preview or Photos apps, and other apps that use Apple’s RAW support are similarly hampered.

To alleviate this increasingly severe problem, both RAW Power and Nitro include Enhanced RAW Support, which adds support for a large number of cameras and formats that Apple has not chosen to support. Nitro and RAW Power add this support in a unique way that extends Apple’s decoding capabilities. All of the same RAW editing controls are available for Enhanced RAW - so you are getting the quality decode and editing features. New cameras are added all the time. A few highlights of this support:

  • Fujifilm Compressed Format
  • Nikon HE and HE* formats
  • GoPro RAW files
  • High resolution modes for Olympus and other camera companies

Some images that are processed through Enhanced RAW Support do not receive automatic lens correction, but many do. Fujifilm Compressed RAW, Nikon HE/HE* and others get lens correction. If your image does not, you will need to use the manual Lens Correction Adjustment, which is described here. The best part about Enhanced RAW Support is that it is transparent to you. Images simply work.

RAW images that are not supported by Apple will appear blank in Photos. However, once you edit them in Nitro, then Nitro will create a full-size JPEG (or HEIF) and store that in the Photo Library. After that, you can view the image in Photos. However, if you revert to original (either in Nitro or Photos), the image will be blank again in Photos.

When using the Nitro Photo Extension, you can still benefit from Enhanced RAW Support, though the image will look blank in Photos. However, when you open it in the Photo Extension, the image will be decoded and will be editable. Like the Nitro standalone app, when saving the edits, the edited image will be visible in Photos.

The camera support list is maintained on the website, and it varies across operating system versions. The latest version can be found here.

Another solution to the lack of camera support is to convert images to DNG format. That will preserve lens correction (when possible). There are pros and cons to converting to DNG which are beyond the scope of this document.

Settings (esp. Standard RAW Development and such)

Back to top

Nitro has a large collection of preferences, or settings. They are described below. Some of the items have help strings and so they are not included here.
Appearance
docs.text:
• Always Use Dark Mode: Nitro defaults to running in dark mode. If you want to use the system setting for dark mode, then turn this off.
  • Viewer Background: You can set the background for images in the Viewer here. The default is 18% gray which is a neutral gray to the human eye.

docs.title: Interface
docs.text:
• Use Command Keys for Rating: this switches the rating keys from single keystrokes (1, 2, 3, 4, 5) to Cmd-1 through Cmd-5.
  • Automatically Advance when Flagging / Rating: you can enable these settings to advance to the next image when rating or flagging. This only works when displaying the viewer, not in the grid view.
  • Place Info & Edit on the Left Side: you can swap the controls so that Info and Edit are on the left side of the interface.
  • Always Make Tabbed Windows (macOS only): when you make a new browser, turn this on to get tabs rather than separate windows.
  • Double Click to Zoom Image: if you enable this, then double-click will zoom the image rather than return to the grid.
  • Tighter zoom levels below 100%: Zoom In / Out changes by 10% rather than 25%.
  • Increased Precision for Some Exif Keys: increases the number of decimal points shown in ExifTool output.
  • Do Not Hide Sidebar Automatically: keeps the sidebar visible when displaying the One Up Viewer.
  • Snap Sliders near Default Values: when editing, if the slider value is near its default value, the app will snap it there. However, if you do not like this behavior, you can turn it off here.

### Editing

  • Calculate Histogram with Display P3: this will switch the histogram from sRGB to Display P3, which is useful if you plan to export files to the Display P3 color profile.
  • Configure Editing Options: this lets you reorder adjustments in the Edit interface as well as control whether adjustments automatically collapse to save space.
  • RAW + JPEG: Edit JPEG By Default: this switches the default for RAW+JPEG from editing the RAW to editing the JPEG.

docs.title: Photo Library Editing
docs.text:
• Update Photo Library Automatically: if this is on, then edits in Nitro will be saved to the Photo Library immediately upon the edit finishing. On macOS Ventura and iOS 16, Photos will display a confirmation dialog. If this is off, then you will need to use the Export interface to update the photo library (see the Export section for more information).
  • File Format: when edits are saved to the Photo Library, the list of edit parameters are stored, as well as a rendered full-size image that includes those edits. Here, you can choose the file format for those full-size images. Apple only permits JPEG and HEIF file formats for full-size rendered images in the library. Changes to this settings, and the remaining two in this section, affect all future edits, but not previously saved ones.
  • Color Profile: lets you set the color profile for full size images stored in the Photo Library. If you use a wide gamut profile like Display P3, it’s best to also use HEIF-10 rather than HEIF-8 or JPEG to avoid banding.
  • Image Quality: set the compression ratio for full-size images.

docs.title: Auto Lens Correction
docs.text:
• Apply Lens Correction When Possible: you can let Nitro automatically correct images when it can determine a good correction based on previous corrections you made manually (see Lens Correction for more details).
  • Only Apply Auto Lens Correction to RAWs: Camera-generated JPEGs usually have lens correction already applied, so this usually should be set to ON to avoid applying a duplicate correction. However, if the camera doesn’t apply correction, or an insufficient one, then turning this on can make sense.

docs.title: Purchase Status
docs.text: This section lets you view your current active purchase(s) of Nitro. In addition, you can manage any Nitro subscription you have (displaying Apple’s interface for this). If you have a lifetime purchase or are using the trial, then the Manage Subscription button will be disabled. The View Prices button lets you display the paywall in case you want to switch to a different plan (for example, purchase the lifetime option while on subscription, or if you want to buy something while still on the trial).
